title: How to Sew a Round Tablecloth: Easy Visual Steps

steps.title: Measure the diameter of the tabletop.
steps.content: Measure the diameter of the tabletop. [1] X Expert Source Donna Serino Dry Cleaning & Alterations Specialist Expert Interview. 31 August 2021. Also measure the length from the tabletop to the floor if you want to make a round tablecloth that stretches to the floor. [2] X Research source If you don't want the homemade tablecloth to reach the floor, measure the distance you'd like it to fall to. [3] X Expert Source Donna Serino Dry Cleaning & Alterations Specialist Expert Interview. 31 August 2021. For example, if you will be sitting at the table, you may want the cloth to fall just above your legs.

steps.title: Determine how much fabric you need.
steps.content: Determine how much fabric you need. Add the tabletop's diameter to twice the length of the finished tablecloth.

steps.title: Cut a length of fabric that measures the diameter plus twice the length, plus 1 inch (2.54 cm) for a hem.
steps.content: Cut a length of fabric that measures the diameter plus twice the length, plus 1 inch (2.54 cm) for a hem.

steps.title: Place the 2 lengths of fabric on top of each other, right-sides facing each other.
steps.content: Place the 2 lengths of fabric on top of each other, right-sides facing each other. Pin the fabrics together along 1 long "wrong" side. [4] X Research source Only do this if your fabric is not wide enough to cover then entire table. For example, if your tabletop is 36 inches (.91 m) across and the finished homemade tablecloth will be 18 inches (.45 m) long, you'll need a piece of fabric that measures 72 inches (1.83 m) square.

steps.title: Sew the fabrics together along the pinned side, .5 inch (1.27 cm) away from the edge.
steps.content: Sew the fabrics together along the pinned side, .5 inch (1.27 cm) away from the edge.

steps.title: Unfold the fabrics, and iron the seam flat.
steps.content: Unfold the fabrics, and iron the seam flat.

steps.title: Trim the width of the fabric so it covers the size of the round tablecloth plus 1 inch (2.54 cm) for the hem.
steps.content: Trim the width of the fabric so it covers the size of the round tablecloth plus 1 inch (2.54 cm) for the hem.

steps.title: Fold the piece of fabric in half, right side facing in.
steps.content: Fold the piece of fabric in half, right side facing in. Fold it in half again, the opposite way, so that you have a square of fabric 1/4 the size of the original piece. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Set the tape measure diagonally across the folded fabric, from the folded corner to the opposite corner.
steps.content: Set the tape measure diagonally across the folded fabric, from the folded corner to the opposite corner. Measure half the finished size of the round tablecloth from the top corner, and make a mark at that point on the fabric.

steps.title: Draw a curved line from that mark to the top outer corner and another from that mark to the bottom inner corner.
steps.content: Draw a curved line from that mark to the top outer corner and another from that mark to the bottom inner corner.

steps.title: Cut the fabric along the lines you just drew.
steps.content: Cut the fabric along the lines you just drew. When you unfold the tablecloth fabric, you should have a perfect circle.

steps.title: Iron the circle flat to remove any creases creating by folding the fabric.
steps.content: Iron the circle flat to remove any creases creating by folding the fabric. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Hem the homemade tablecloth.
steps.content: Hem the homemade tablecloth. Fold under the edge of the circle 1/4 inch (.64 cm), and fold it under another 3/4 inch (1.9 cm). Pin and then sew the hem.
